newsitem.title: USA: Schwab posts 21 percent rise in profits.
newsitem.headline: Schwab posts 21 percent rise in profits.

text.p: Charles Schwab Corp. said Friday that its profits rose by 21 percent in the third quarter as the brokerage firm's 1996 revenues and net income continued to grow at a record pace.

The San Francisco-based company said its net income for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose to $57.1 million, or 32 cents a share, from $47.2 million, or 26 cents a share, despite shifting market conditions.
Revenues for the quarter rose to $430 million from $385.5 million, the company said, adding that both revenue and net income for the first nine months of the year were the highest in its history.

The company said that so far this year it earned $174.1 million, or 97 cents a share, on revenues of $1.37 billion, up from net income of $130 million, or 73 cents a share, on revenues of $1.03 billion.

Schwab, which has 235 branch offices across the country and also offers electronic trading, said its commission revenues were comparable to the year-ago period but strong growth in non-trading revenues helped it post a 12 percent overall increase in revenues for the third quarter.

"While revenue growth for the quarter fell short of our long-term threshold of 20 percent annual growth, year-to-date growth in revenues and earnings per share exceeds 30 percent," Chairman Charles Schwab said in a statement.

"Our flexible cost structure and ongoing focus on expenses enabled the company to achieve a 13 percent after-tax profit margin and an annualized return on equity of 29 percent for the quarter, exceeding our long-term thresholds of 10 and 20 percent, respectively," Schwab added.
Schwab's stock gained $1.25 to $24.25 in early afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
